title: Buoyant force blocks at different depths

content.question: At the instant shown in the figure, Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are both completely submerged in a liquid. The center of Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> below the surface of the water, and the center of Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is a distance <math alttext="3 d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>d</mi></math> below the surface. The mass of Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and the mass of Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math>. The blocks have the same volume. The buoyant force on Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is <math alttext="F sub B comma 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>,</mo><mtext>1</mtext></mrow></msub></math> and the buoyant force on Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is <math alttext="F sub B comma 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="F sub B comma 1, end sub, to F sub B comma 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> ?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
